head.title: Decay on several sorts of heterogeneous centers: Special monodisperse approximation in the situation of strong unsymmetry. 4. Numerical results for the approximation of essential asymptotes

article.h1: Decay on several sorts of heterogeneous centers: Special monodisperse approximation in the situation of strong unsymmetry. 4. Numerical results for the approximation of essential asymptotes

div.p: This manuscript directly continues [1], [2], [3]. All definitions and formulas have to be taken from [1]. The numerical results for comparison with the total monodisperse approximation has to be taken from [2]. The numerical results for the floating monodisperse approximation can be taken from [3].
We have to recall again the system of the condensation equations. It can be written in the following form

semantics.annotation: italic-G RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x

italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e italic-x italic-p OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-b INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x CLOSE:)

div.p: with a positive parameter bğ‘italic-bb and have to estimate the error in

semantics.annotation: italic-N RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x

div.p: with some parameter lğ‘™italic-ll.
We shall solve this problem numerically and compare our result with the already formulated models. In the model of the total monodisperse approximation we get

semantics.annotation: italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x

div.p: where GAsubscriptğºğ´italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG_{A} is

semantics.annotation: italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-b ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-b italic-D CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: and the constant Dğ·italic-DD is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-D RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.28

div.p: Numerical results are shown in [2].
In the model of the floating monodisperse approximation we have to calculate the integral

semantics.annotation: italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x

div.p: where GBsubscriptğºğµitalic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG_{B} is

semantics.annotation: italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-b ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-b INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-b ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-b OPEN:( Theta OPEN:( italic-D ADDOP:minus italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 ADDOP:plus Theta OPEN:( italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus italic-D CLOSE:) italic-D CLOSE:) CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: Numerical results are shown in [3].

It is very attractive to spread the approximation for the last integral at small zğ‘§italic-zz for all zğ‘§italic-zz (as it was done in the intermediate situation in [4] when we solved the algebraic equation on the parameters of the spectrum (in the intermediate situation it is absolutely justified). Then we came to the third approximation

semantics.annotation: italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x

div.p: where GCsubscriptğºğ¶italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG_{C} is

semantics.annotation: italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-b ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-b italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: This approximation will be called as â€approximation of essential asymptotesâ€. The real advantage of this approximation is the absence of the exponential nonlinearity. When this approximation will be introduced into equation on the parameters of the condensation process there will be no numerical difficulties to solve it.

We have tried all mentioned approximations for bğ‘italic-bb from 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 up to 5.25.2NUMBER:5.25.2 with the step 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 and for lğ‘™italic-ll from 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 up to 5.25.2NUMBER:5.25.2 with a step 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2. We calculate the relative error in Nğ‘italic-NN. The results are drawn in fig.1 for NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} where the relative errors are marked by r3subscriptğ‘Ÿ3italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{3}.

We see that the relative errors of NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} are very small and practically the same. One can not find the difference between fig.1 in [3] and fig.1 here.

The maximum of errors in NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} lies near l=0ğ‘™0italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0l=0. So, we have to analyse the situation with small values of lğ‘™italic-ll. It was done in fig.2 for NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C}. We see that we can not find the maximum error because it increases at small bğ‘italic-bb. Then we have to calculate the situation with b=0ğ‘0italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:0b=0. Here we have to solve the following equation

semantics.annotation: italic-G RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x

div.p: and to compare

semantics.annotation: italic-N RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-G CLOSE:) italic-d italic-x

div.p: with

semantics.annotation: italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-D italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-d italic-z

italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l OPEN:( Theta OPEN:( italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus italic-D CLOSE:) italic-D italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus Theta OPEN:( italic-D ADDOP:minus italic-z MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) italic-d italic-z

italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-l italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-d italic-z

div.p: We can not put here l=0ğ‘™0italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0l=0 directly.

The results are shown in fig.3. One can see one curve with two wings. The upper wing corresponds to the error of NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{A} and the lower corresponds to the relative error in NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C}. At l=0ğ‘™0italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0l=0 these wings come together. We see that our hypothesis (the worst situation for the floating monodisperse approximation takes place when the first type heterogeneous centers are unexhausted) is really true.

The worst situation is when bğ‘italic-bb is near zero and lğ‘™italic-ll lies also near zero. Here we can use the total monodisperse approximation to estimate the error. It is clear that the relative error in NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{A} is greater than in NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} (not in NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C}). So, we can calculate r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{1}, see that when bğ‘italic-bb goes to zero it decreases (it is clear also from the physical reasons) and estimate the error r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{2} at b=0ğ‘0italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:0b=0, l=0ğ‘™0italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0l=0 by R1subscriptğ‘…1italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{1} calculated at small bğ‘italic-bb and l=0ğ‘™0italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0l=0. Then one can see that it is small.

An interesting problem is to see whether NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} are different or no. Earlier we can not see the difference. In fig.4 one can see the ratio r2/r3subscriptğ‘Ÿ2subscriptğ‘Ÿ3italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{2}/r_{3} plotted at b=0ğ‘0italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:0b=0 and can note that only for lâ‰ˆ0.01Ã·0.02ğ‘™0.010.02italic-l RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.01 MULOP:divide NUMBER:0.02l\approx 0.01\div 0.02 one can see the small difference. It means that to see the difference between these approximations the ratio between the scale of the first type centers nucleation and the scale of the second type centers nucleation must be giant. Even at giant values the difference is small.

li.span: V.B.Kurasov, Deponed in VINITI 2594B95 from 19.09.1995, 28 p.

p.span: The relative error of NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} drawn as the function of lğ‘™italic-ll and bğ‘italic-bb. Parameter lğ‘™italic-ll goes from 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 up to 5.25.2NUMBER:5.25.2 with a step 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2. Parameter bğ‘italic-bb goes from 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 up to 5.25.2NUMBER:5.25.2 with a step 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2.

One can see the maximum at small lğ‘™italic-ll and moderate bğ‘italic-bb. One can not separate NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} according to fig.1 in [3] and fig.1.

div.p: Fig.2

p.span: The relative error of NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} drawn as the function of lğ‘™italic-ll and bğ‘italic-bb. Parameter lğ‘™italic-ll goes from 0.010.01NUMBER:0.010.01 up to 0.110.11NUMBER:0.110.11 with a step 0.010.01NUMBER:0.010.01. Parameter bğ‘italic-bb goes from 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2 up to 5.25.2NUMBER:5.25.2 with a step 0.20.2NUMBER:0.20.2.

One can see the maximum at small lğ‘™italic-ll and small bğ‘italic-bb. One can note that now the values of bğ‘italic-bb corresponding to maximum of the relative errors become small. One can not separate NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C} according to fig.2 in [3] and fig.2 here.

semantics.annotation: italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: Fig.3

p.span: One can see two wings which come together for bğ‘italic-bb near 00NUMBER:0. The upper wing corresponds to the relative error of NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{A}. The lower wing corresponds to the relative errors of NBsubscriptğ‘ğµitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{B} and NCsubscriptğ‘ğ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{C}. One can not separate them.

One can see that r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{1} decreases when bğ‘italic-bb goes to 00NUMBER:0 and can estimate r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{2} by r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{1} at small lğ‘™italic-ll.

semantics.annotation: italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

div.p: Fig.4

p.span: One can see the difference between r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{2} and r3subscriptğ‘Ÿ3italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{3} only at very small values of bğ‘italic-bb (only the first two points corresponding to l=0.01ğ‘™0.01italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01l=0.01 and l=0.02ğ‘™0.02italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.02l=0.02). So, N3subscriptğ‘3italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{3} can be also considered as a suitable approximation.
